results.title: Stelarc Moving Image Collection
results.brief_description:
The Stelarc Collection is the moving image archive of Australian performance artist Stelarc. The collection consists of documentation of events and performances throughout the career of the pioneering body artist from the 1970s to the 2000s. Renowned for pushing his body to its limits through durational performance, body modification and surgical enhancement, Stelarc has established a decades-long practice that explores the intersection between the human body and technology, proposing a post-human understanding of the world. This unique archive of video and photographic documentation spans the artist’s early hook suspensions and internal body probes to performances with a robotic third arm and experiments in virtual realities.

The collection is housed on a variety of formats used since the introduction of video in the 1970s, including reel-to-reel tape, VHS, U-Matic, SP Betacam and Mini DV. These variable formats are currently being digitised to ensure the preservation and legacy of the artist’s archive.

The Stelarc Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the artist through the Cultural Gifts Program.

images.caption: [Stelarc: Event for Modified Man 1976] (Stelarc) Digital Access Still

results.title: [Stelarc: Event for Modified Man 1976]
results.brief_description:
This video is documentation of a performance entitled “Modulate / Meditate: Event for Modified Man” held at Tamura Gallery in Tokyo, Japan, from 26 January to 1 February 1976.

In this durational performance, Stelarc has hooks inserted into his back and sews first his lips and then his eyelids closed with a needle and thread. In the gallery are TV monitors including one showing an X-ray of his own body. Standing in the centre of the gallery with the hooks attached to the wall behind him, the artist captures the sounds of his own body – heartbeat, breath and blood rushing – which are then amplified throughout the space. In the latter part of the video, the participation of the body comes to an end: the artist removes the stitches from his eyelids and mouth and the hooks are removed.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.

results.title: [Stelarc: Stretched Skin No.4 Munich 1977]
results.brief_description:
This video footage is of a suspension performance entitled “Event for Stretched Skin No. 4” that took place at the Art Academy in Munich, Germany on 8 August 1977.

As the name suggests, this was Stelarc’s fourth suspension performance, in which the artist’s body is suspended in space by a series of hooks inserted into the skin. The artist began performing these durational performances in Japan in 1976; this was his first international performance.

In the video, we see the hooks being pierced into the skin across the back and front of the body. The body is then suspended upside down from a sculptural structure made out of logs of wood. The body hangs with arms outstretched in front of the windows of the Art Academy, showing Munich in the background. The performance is observed by a team of assistants, photographers and a small audience.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.

results.title: The Calling
results.creator_credit: Jodie Passmore, Bridget Ikin, Felix Media and Angelica Mesiti
results.credit_line:
Angelica Mesiti

Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection

Three channel video installation, digital video, sound, 35:26

Courtesy the artist and Anna Schwartz Gallery
results.material_description: three channel video, projection, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
‘The Calling’ is a three-channel video installation that focuses on whistling languages, ancient forms of non-verbal communication which are still used in 2013 to communicate in isolated and difficult landscapes.

To conduct research for ‘The Calling’, artist Angelica Mesiti travelled to the village of Kuskoy in Northern Turkey, the island of La Gomera in The Canary Islands and the Island of Evia in Greece where whistling languages are all still in use.

For these communities, whistling languages are in a process of transformation from their traditional use as tools for communication across vast lands into tourist attractions and cultural artefacts and are being taught to local school children.

‘The Calling’ is a poignant exploration of ancient human traditions evolving and adapting to the modern world. The work speaks to the tenacity and creativity of traditional cultures in the face of globalisation, technological progress and environmental flux.

This exhibition is the work of Sydney/Paris-based artist Angelica Mesiti, winner of the inaugural Ian Potter Moving Image Commission.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jodie Passmore, Bridget Ikin, Felix Media and Angelica Mesiti

results.title: Our city cares
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a gesture of support and in sympathy for those affected by Black Saturday the Melbourne community came together at Federation Square on Friday 27 February 2009 to show that the city cares. Visitors left an outline drawing of their hands on paper and wrote words of encouragement and pledges of support as part of the “Healing Hands” initiative.
